facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 370 and 371 of 1960 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1956 of the High Court of Nagpur in Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 22 and 274 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 370 and 371 of 1960. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1956, of the former High Court of judicature at Nagpur  number High Court of Madhya Pradesh at jabalpur  in Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 22 and 274 of 1955.

facts.text: Respondent 1, Seth Balkishan Nathani, was the proprietor and lambardar of Mouza Sonpairi in Tahsil and District Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in Appeal No. 370 of 1960 may be stated first. Respondent 1, Seth Balkishan Nathani, was the proprietor and lambardar of Mouza Sonpairi in Tahsil and District Raipur.

facts.text: On January 14, 1947, Seth Balkishan Nathani executed perpetual pattas in favour of his wife Vashodabai (since deceased) and respondents 4, 5 and 6 in respect of khudkasht and grass lands of Mouza Sonpairi.

anchor.surface_text: On January 14, 1947. he executed perpetual pattas in favour of his wife, Vashodabai, since deceased, and respondents 4, 5 and 6 in respect of khudkasht and grass lands of Mouzz Sonpairi.

facts.text: In Tabdili jamabandi of the year 1946-47 the said lands were recorded as the Occupancy Tenancy Holdings of respondents 4 to 6 and respondent 2, Govindlal Nathani, the legal representative of Vashodabai.

anchor.surface_text: In Tabdili jamabandi of the year 1946-47 the said lands were recorded as the Occupancy Tenancy Holdings of the said respondents 4 to 6 and respondent 2, Govindlal Nathani, the legal representative of Vashodabai.

facts.text: The Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights, Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, 1951 (1 of 1951) came into force on January 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Right,,  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1956  1 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Act, came into force on January 22, 1951.

facts.text: The estate of the proprietor was notified under s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, in due companyrse the estate of the said proprietor was duly numberified under s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: On March 25, 1952, the Deputy Commissioner, Land Reforms, acting under S. 40 of the Act, recognized Balkishan Nathani as the pattadar and settled the assessment payable by him in respect of Khasra Nos. 28912 and 366/7 of Mouza Sonpairi.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1952, the Deputy Commissioner, Laid Reforms, acting under S. 40 of the Act, recognized the said Balkishan Nathani as the pattadar and settled the assessment payable by him in respect of Khasra Nos. 28912 and 366/7 of Mouza Sonpairi.

facts.text: No appeal was preferred against the order dated March 25, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: No appeal was preferred against that order.

facts.text: Appellant 2, the Nistar Officer cum Additional Deputy Commissioner Raipur, started proceedings against the respondent for the correction of old annual papers in Mouza Sonpairi to reopen the earlier order under s. 40.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, appellant 2, the Nistar Officer cum Additional Deputy Commissioner Raipur, started proceedings against the respondent for the companyrection of old annual papers in MouzSonpairi. with a view to reopen the earlier order made under s. 40 of the Act,

facts.text: Respondent 1 raised objection that appellant 2 had no jurisdiction to initiate the proceedings; objection overruled by appellant 2.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1, Seth Balkishan Nathani, raised a. objection that appellant 2 had numberjurisdiction to initiate the proceedings. Appellant 2 overruled the objection

facts.text: Appellant 2 made an order fixing hearing for 4-8-1954 and directing production of witnesses for proving cultivation and obtaining sale-deeds from purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: and made the following order On the next hearing, 5, witnesses may be produced for proving cultivation. The names of the purchasers, to whom the lands have been sold, be obtained from the Patwari, and a numberice be served on them that they should file their statements as well as should bring the sale-deeds along with them. Hearing fixed for date 4-8-1954.

facts.text: Respondent 1 preferred an appeal from that order to the Board of Revenue, Madhya Pradesh, which was dismissed as premature.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent I preferred an appeal from that order to the Board of Revenue, Madhya Pradesh, but the same was Dismissed on the ground that it was premature.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petition No. 22 of 1955 in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: hereupon, the respondents filed the writ petition No. 22 of 1955 in the High Court of Madhya pradesh.

facts.text: Respondent 1 was the Proprietor and lambardar of patti No. 1 of Mouza Kachna in Tahsil and District Raipur.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 371 of 1960 relates to patti To. 1 of Mouza Kachna in Tahsil and District kaipur. Respondent I was the Proprietor and ambardar of the said Mouza.

facts.text: On February 19, 1948, Seth Balkishan Nathani executed perpetual pattas in respect of the said lands in favour of respondents 2 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1948, the said Seth Balkishan Nathani executed perpetual pattas in respect of the said lands in favour of the same respondents as in the other appeal.

facts.text: In the annual papers the said lands were recorded as the Occupancy Tenancy Holdings of respondents 2 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: In he annual papers the said lands were recorded as the Occupancy Tenancy Holdings of respondents 2 to 6.

facts.text: On December 8, 1954, appellant 2 made an inspection of the said lands.

anchor.surface_text: on December 8, 1954, appellant 2 made an inspection of the said lands and made the following order on December 9, 1954

facts.text: On December 9, 1954, appellant 2 made an order finding obvious mistakes in Government documents, bogus transfers by ex-proprietors to family members, and corrected the Patwari papers after spot inspection.

anchor.surface_text: There were found to be obvious mistakes in Government documents-Khasra,Jamabandi and Tabdilat. Mistakes discharged  discovered  by me in Patwari papers have been companyrected. Ex-proprietors  1  Balkishan Nathani and others and  2  Narayanrao made absolutely bogus transfers in favour of their family members, namely,  i .  a  Kamlabai,  b  Pana Bai, Yashoda bai,  d  Chhote Bai of Nathani family.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petition No. 274 of 1955 in the High Court to quash the order dated December 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed writ petition No. 274 of 1955 in the High Court to quash the said order.

facts.text: A Full Bench of the High Court allowed the two writ petitions, quashed the proceedings and the order dated December 9, 1954, and prohibited further proceedings affecting occupancy tenancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the High Court held that neither s. 15  3  of the Act number s. 47  1  of the Central Provinces Land Revenue Act, 1917  C. P. Act No. II of 1917 , hereinafter called the Land Revenue Act, companyferred a power-on the Nistar officer to review orders already made... In the result, it allowed the two writ petitions quashing the proceedings started by the Nistar officer in the case of Mouza Sonpairi and the order dated December 9, 1954,

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: The second petitioner died after arguments heard by High Court and before judgment; petition to set aside abatement dismissed.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Act which authorizes the Deputy Commissioner to review an order made by him under the said sub-section and, therefore, an order made by him, subject to appeal, becomes final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute lacks any review provision for s.40 orders; only appeal under s.84 available, making orders final post-appeal period.

holdings.text: Under s. 15 (3) of the Act, the authority concerned can review an order made by him under s. 13 of the Act... Neither s. 13 nor s. 15 (3) has any relevance in the context of an order made by the Deputy Commissioner under s. 40 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned counsel for the appellants contends that s. 15 (3) of the Act confers such a power. Under s. 15 (3) of the Act, the authority concerned can review an order made by him under s. 13 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.15(3) limited to reviewing Compensation Officer orders under s.13 on compensation and vesting details; inapplicable to Deputy Commissioner's s.40 occupancy determinations.

anchor.surface_text: Mangloo v. Board of Revenue  1 . The facts in that case were that on the death of one Gaindoo who was a tenant of mouzu Matia, on an application made by his nephew and his widow, their names were entered in the annual papers as joint tenants of the land by the Assistant Superintendent of Land Records there-

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 47(1) of the Land Revenue Act deals only with preparation of annual papers and not correction of erroneous entries therein
precedents.cited_holding: As we read section 47 1  of the Act and the rules governing it, we are of opinion that these provisions deal only with the preparation of the annual papers and number with their companyrection if the entries are found to be erroneous

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1954 Nag. 143, 146. provisions deal only with the preparation of the annual papers and number with their companyrection if the entries are found to be erroneous. They are only enabling provisions which import numberrestriction on the power of the Revenue Officers to companyrect the mistakes or remove any irregularities, companymitted in the preparation of the annual papers. Neither the annual papers number the companyrected entries affect any questions of title or vested interest, of any party. The power of the. Revenue Officers in this regard, is analogous to the untrammelled right of a person to companyrect his private documents, which cannot be questioned in a Court of law by any one whose right or interest is number affected thereby.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 47(1) of the Land Revenue Act deals only with preparation of annual papers and not correction of erroneous entries therein
